What kinde of man you ſpeake ſo groſſely to.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Will you get hence? know you how ſtands your caſe?
If you diſturbe vs here, Ile giue you cauſe
To thinke vpon this time, this place, and me:
Whil'ſt you haue day to liue;

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I pittie you,
That ſeeke to make ſo great a man your ſoe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ile cracke your crowne ſir if you get not hence.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why what art thou?
What mean'ſt?
What buſ'neſſe haſt thou with her?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt know
Firſt I affirme the maiden is free borne.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: And my ſiſter.
I therefore now forwarne thee ſouldier,
Thou vſe no force againſt her. Thais, He go
And fetch her Nurſe Sophrona hither ſtraight;
And ſhew her theſe remembrances.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Dooſt thou
Forewarne me that I ſhould not touch my owne?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I ſay I do forewarne thee.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Here you ſir,
You haue good action of deceit againſt him.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: What's our courſe
Now Gnato?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Why let's retreat: ſheel ſtraight come after you,
Crouching and kneeling.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Nay
That's ſure.
I am acquainted with theſe womens humors:
Sue, they are ſqueamiſh; if you keepe off, they ſue.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Shall I diſmiſſe the
Armie?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Sanga, as fits good ſouldiers,
Caſt now your eyes backe on the houſehold chimnels

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: My minde was long ago among the platters

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.p: All follow me this way in.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: COntinueſt drabbe to talke in riddles to me?
I know, I know not, heard ſo, he is gone,
I was not by —. Wilt thou not in plaine tearmes
Tell me the matter? the maides cloathes are torne,
She weepes and ſilent keepes, the Eunuch gon.
Why this? what's chanc'd? ſpeakeſt not?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Woes mee
Poore ſoule!
What ſhould I ſay? they ſay he was no Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I haue found it certaine ſo.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Why what a gods name had he here to do?
Or why was hither brought?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
But that I gueſſe he loued Pamphila.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I find my ſelfe accurſed wretch vndone,
If this be true thou vtterſt. Iſt for that,
The wench ſo weepes?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Thinkſt ſo hegge?
Was this the charge I left you at my parting?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What ſhould I do? I left 'him both alone
As you did bidde.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Vnluckie queane, thou left's
A lambe to the woolfe: oh I am aſham'd,
sp.stage: Enter Chaerea in the Eunuchs cloathes.
sp.l: So to be plaid on. What man haue we here?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Miſtreſſe, for Gods loue peace; we are well
W'haue caught
The man.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Looke to your left hand.
Do you not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Call out for helpe;
To lay hold on him with all ſpeede you can.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What ſhall's do with him foole?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What do, • 'you aske?
Pray marke if when you wiſtlie eye the fellow,
Has not a aſhameleſſe leere?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Note with what confidence my man ſtruts too.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: AS I but now to Antiphoes did come,
His father and his mother were at home;
As if't had beene ſo plotted ſo that in
I could not enter butt I muſt be ſeene.
Whil'ſt here about the doore a while I ſtay,
One that I knew came but into my way:
I him eſpying haſtily betooke
Me to my heeles; and fled into a nooke
Was vnfrequented: ſo from place to place
Poſted, till I to death nigh wearied was:
And this I did, leaſt any ſhould me know.
But is not this Thais, I ſee? tis ſhe:
I ſticke ith'mire; nor know I what to do.
But what care I? what dare ſhe do to me?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Let's to him. O, you are well met honeſt Dorus.
Tell me, didſt runne away?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: And was it well done, thinkſt thou?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Thinkſt to go with't ſcot free ſo away?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Forgiue me but this one fault, if I euer
Commit the like againe, then kill me for't.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: I feard your maid here would tell tales of me.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Impudence
A trifle? is't a trifle in thine eye
To take a freeborne maid, and rauiſh her?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: I tooke her for my fellow ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Fellow?
I ſearſe can hold my ſingers from his eares.
Monſter art come againe, to flout vs too?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Pray forſooth, why ſo?
I thinke I ow't the gallowes, if I do
As I do threaten; and the rather too,
Becauſe he does confeſſe he's ſlaue to you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: No more of this. Chaerea, you haue committed
sp.l: An act faire vnbeſeeming that faire port
Your ſelfe and friends here beare; ſay the ſcorne fitted
And to my courſe of life did ruſtly ſorte:
Yet for your owne worth you ſhould haue forborne.
Nor truely know I now what courſe to frame
Touching the maid; you haue diſorderd ſo
All my proceedings, I cannot returne
Her to her friends, as I deſird the ſame;
And as was fitting for the maid to goe:
So that both maid and friends I might haue made
Beholding to me, by the courſe I laid.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Thais, but now I hope hencefoorth will grow
Faſt loue betweene vs: oftentimes you know
From bad beginnings, ſlight occaſion,
Great loue hath had its deriuation.
What, if ſome higher powers did thus decree?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: In ſuch ſenſe I do take it verily;
And ſo do wiſh't.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Pray one thing reckon right
No purpoſd ſcorne, but loues imperiall mihght
Then ſwayd my paſſions.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I beleeue 'twas ſo;
And truly therefore pardon you the rather:
I am not (Chaerea) of ſuch ſtubborne nature,
Nor ſo vnskild as loues power not to know.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: So helpe me God as I now grow in loue
With you to Thais.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Then miſtreſſe I perceaue
You ought to watch him.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Introth le truſt thee for iuſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: Thais, I do commend, commit my ſelfe
To your protection; begge your helpe herein;
Deſire, beſeech you'l ſtand my Patroneſſe.
I cannot liue if I not marrie her.

sp.speaker: Chae
sp.l: Tſh, what? I know he will—
So ſhe be knowne freeborne.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: If you pleaſe ſtay
A little, the maides brother will be here;
He went to call the nurſe that nur'ſt her young:
You may be by at her acknowledging.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: And in the meane time will You.
(Till he do come) we go into my houſe?
Tis better then at doore here waiting ſtand.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Pray what d'ye meane to do?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: D'you aske? meane you for all this yet
To let him come againe into the houſe?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Take my word for't, h'le aduenture
Some ſecond battrie.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Ha'you not had ſufficient triall of him?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Ile not truſt you, Chaerea.
Vnleſſe you be kept out.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: But (Pythias)
Thy ſelfe ſhalt be my keeper

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Troth not I:
Ile neither truſt thee with the cuſtodie
Of any thing, not keepe thee yet my ſelfe.
So get you hence.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I'm loſt, pray let vs in, I would not (Thais)
He ſee me in this habite in the ſtreete.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Yes truth? alacke!
A maiden batchelor I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Go in before, I follow. Pythias
Tarrte you here, to bring in Chremes with you.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: WHat, can I thinke of no plot, no deuice,
No tricke to erie quittance with this raſcall?
That foiſted in this counterfeit among vs?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: Pray moue your ioynts a little nimbler ruiſe.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: I, I ſee't; but nothing forward.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Haue you yet ſhewn the tokens to her ſir?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: What ſayes ſhe, pray? remembers them?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: In troth you bring good newes,
For Ido wiſh the maid well. Pray go in;
My miſtreſſe long ſince did expect your comming.
But ſee the honeſt fellow Parmeno,
I thinke I haue found a tricke to nettle him,
As I would wiſh. Ile firſt go in and heare
The maides acknowledgement; and againe come foorth
To fright the rogue with a fine pennie worth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I Now ſcout out, to ſee what Chaerea has done:
Who if he haue the buſineſſe cleanely handled,
Good gods! What glorious palme haue I then wonne?
For to omit, that I a cafeintangled
Haue wound out fairely to his hand; haue wrought,
Haue compaſſed his loue, his wench, a maid
He ſo did dote on: and yet coſt him nought,
(No purſe expence, no trouble, hazard made;)
And from a greedie harlot. Then agen
(Which I indeed accompt my Maſters priſe)
That I haue found him out a readie meane,
To learne theſe ſtrumpets manners and full guiſe:
Which ripely vnderſtood, he may for euer
Deteſt their courſes: when abroad they git,
None are more neate and ſweete in their behauiour,
They mince and picke vpon each daintie bit;
(With their friend eating ſuch is their demeanor.)
And then to note their greedie rauening,
Their ſluttiſhneſſe, their penurie at home;
What naſtie Cormorants they are alone;
Out of ſtale porrage muſty bread deuouring:
Theſe things are youths true cordialls being knowne.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: ROague for thy deeds & words Ile plague thee ſo.
Thou ſhalt not for our wrongs hece ſcot-free go.
Your mercie oh good gods' oh cruell practiſe!
Alas poore youth! but ô that curſed vilaine!
That vilaine Parmeno, that brought him hither!

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: It pitties me;
Therefore I haſted out o' doores, poore woman:
Becauſe I would not ſee't. Oh, what example
(Say the) they do intend to make of him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: ô God! What ſtrange ſtirre's this? am not I loſt, trow?
Ile to her. What meanes this flight, Pythias?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Dooſt aske audacious fellow? whilſt thou ſoughtſt
To put a tricke vpon vs, th'haſt vndone,
Haſt vterly vndone that prettie youth,
Thou broughteſt vs for an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Dooſt know the maid was ſent vs is free borne?
And has a brother here of great accompt?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: But ſhe's prou'd ſo: this poore youth
Has rauiſht her; which when her brother heard of.
Comming in furious heate—

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I, although Thais beggd the contrarie.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: And now he further threatneth
To vſe him in ſuch ſort, as is the wont
To be perform'd vpon adulterers.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Vpon what confidence dare he venture
So heynous an attempt?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is't not the heynouſeſt that can be thought on?
Who euer ſaw any one apprehended
For an adulterer in a bawdie houſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But that thou maiſt know't
I tell thee (Pythias) tis my Maſters ſonne.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Therefore let Thais looke then,
She ſuffer him ſuſtaine no iniurie.
But why do I my ſelfe not reſeue him?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Parmeno conſider what you go about.
Leſt you not helpe him, and yet caſt away
Your ſelfe foreuer. For they do imagine
That all is done is of your practiſing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What ſhall I do then wretch? or what contriue.
But lo, I ſee my old Maſter newly come
Out o'the countrey: were I beſt acquaint him
What is befalne or not? Ile tell him, ſure;
Though I do know, I ſhall pay ſoundly for it.
But I muſt doot, that he may helpe his ſonne.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I, thou dooſt wiſely. Ile goe in. Deline.
Euery thing to him, as it chanc'd in order.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: MY Country grange yeelds this commoditie,
I find no irk ſomneſſe in field, or citie:
I can ſhift place, being of either wearie.
But is not yond our Parmeno? tis he.
Who waite you here for before Thais doore?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Who's thats oh Maſter' you are wellcome home.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'm vndone, my Tongue
Falters for ſcare.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: How's this? why ſhakſt thou ſo?
Tell me, 's all well here?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Maſter firſt I craue
You would conceiue the matter as it ſtands:
That what ſo ere hath happend, hath not come
Through any fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Indeede you vrge the queſtion orderly:
I ſhould haue firſt opend the cauſe to you.
Phaedria bought an Eunuch to beſtow
vpon her here

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Bought ſaiſt thou? I am certainely vndone.
What coſt he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Chaerea doos loue a minſtrell wench here.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Ha! Beſides
What, loues ſaiſt thou? doos he alreadie know
What a whore meanes? is he got to towne too?
One miſchiefe broodes another.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Pray you ſir
Do not ſo eye me. This he dooes not do
vpon my ſetting on.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Sirtha, leaue talke
Touching thy ſelfe. If I liue (pillorie)
Ile-but vnfold firſt th' whole bus'neſſe to me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Chaerea was brought to Thais for that Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes ſir, afterward
They haue taken him for an adulterer;
And bound him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pray note (good ſir) theſe ſtrumpets inſolence.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Is there yet any further miſchiefe left,
Or ill vnutterd.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Why ſtay I
From breaking in vpon 'hem?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: There's no doubt
But I incurre ſome famous puniſhment:
But ſince I muſt do't of neceſſitie,
I ioy yet I ſhall worke theſe queanes ſome miſchiefe.
For th'old man long hath ſought occaſion
To plague'hem ſoundly: now at laſt has found one.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: TRroth for this many aday there has not chanced
An accident more pleaſant then this now;
To ſee the old man come in ſo miſtaken:
'T was ſport to me alone of all the reſt,
Who knew the ground of th' error. ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: I'm come forth to
With Parmeno, but where a Gods name is he?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: See where he is, Ile to him meete

sp.speaker: Par
sp.p: What newes with thee now Giglet?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What meanſt thou? why this laughter? goeſt thou on?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, he. Oh-oh-I burſt, I faint
With laughing at thee.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: doſt thou aske?
Vpon my troth I neuer in my life
Knew a more errand foole, nor euer ſhall.
Ha, ha, ha, he—it cannot be expreſſed
What paſtime thou haſt made vs yond' within:
And yet (good truth) at firſt I tooke thee for
A very wiſe and cunning pated fellow.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: What at the firſt daſh
Oughtſt thou to credit euery thing I ſaid?
What didſt thou thinke the brane exploit too little,
The raſh youth ventred through thy ſetting on;
vnleſſe thou further diddſt diſcouer him
vnto his father? prithe, tell me one thing;
What thinkſt thou Cherea thought, when now his father
Found him ſo fine dreſt in an Eunuchs habit?
How iſt? ſeeſt thou yet, thou art ripe for hanging?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How? what ſaiſt thou peſtilent queane, diddſt lye then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And keep'ſt a laughing ſtill too?
Thinkſt thou tis ſuch fine paſtime (harlotrie)
To make a ſcorne of me?

sp.speaker: Par
sp.p: I, if perchance thou carry't away, ſcotfree.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ile crie quittance o' my credit.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Yes ſure. We ſhall haue, time yet, Parmeno:
For thee, thou art to be truſs'd vp preſently;
Who fleſheſt heedleſſe youth in vilanie
And then betraiſt him to diſcouerie.
Father and ſonne will both make thee an example.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.l: Looke you' this y'haue got
For the Eunuch you late vſherd home to vs.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Vnluckie I am caught iuſt like a rat,
Trac'd by my noiſe, mine owne vnheedie chart

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: VVHat do we now? on what hopes? or with what Purpoſe
Do we come hither? what intend you Traſo?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Who, I to yeeld my ſelfe to Thais mercie,
Do all ſhe ſhall inioyne.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why Heſſe, then the valiant Hercuies,

Who condiſcended to ſerue
〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I like the precedent Wo • ld I yet might ſee
Her cracke your crowne once with her pantefle.
What newes? her doore opes.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: what new miſchief's this?
I nere ſaw this man yet: what may it meane,
That he comes foorth ſo haſtily and iocond?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: OH louing countriemen, liues any man
More happie then my ſelfe? troth, I thinke none
The Gods haue ſhewne all their full might on me,
On whom ſo ſodainely ſo many chances,
So many proſperous chances meete in one.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why is he growne ſo merie?

sp.speaker: Gnae.
sp.l: Oh my deareſt,
My kindeſt Parmeno' firſt faſhioner,
Contriuer, finiſher, of all my fortunes;
All my contentments. Knoweſt thou Parmeno
What ioy I am in? heareſt thou my Pamphila
Is found to be free borne?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As God ſhall helpe me, I'm Glad ont.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: do y' heare him what he ſaies?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I ioy beſide
My brother Chedria's loue is now faire ſetled:
W'are made one houſe; Thais hath giu'n vp her ſelfe
Vnto my fathers kindneſſe and protection:
Shee's now our owne.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Then ſhe is all your brothers.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then (that's other cauſe
The ſculdier is caſhierd hence.

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: now I prithee (of ioy)
Giue thou my brother notice of this newes,
Where ere he may be found; and ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ile ſeeke for him at home.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dooſt thou now Gnato
Make any doubt, but I am loſt for euer?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: What ſhould I firſt count on?
Whom chiefely praiſe? or him that counſeld me
Or yet my ſelfe that venturd the performance?
Or ſhall I not yeeld fortune ſhare of praiſe,
Which guided theſe things thus? Which in one day
Hath cloſed vp ſo many, ſo great things,
And all ſo timely orderd? or the eaſie
And pleaſant diſpoſition of my father?
Oh I beſeech thee, gratious Iu •• ter.
Continue to vs this our happineſſe

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Your faith good Gods! What things aboue beleefe
Hath our man told me? but where is my brother?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.l: I well beleeue you, brother
There is none liuing more deſeruing loue
Then this your Thais: ſhe's a furtherer
To all our family

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: Why, how now brother,
Commendſt thou her to me?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am vndone:
The leſſer hope I haue, the more I loue.
Helpe Gnato at a pinch; my truſt's in thee.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: What wold you haue me do?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Win by intreatie,
By money. I may hold ſome place neere Thais.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Come, I know thee Gnato.
If once thou vndertak'ſt a thing—worke this,
And name but what reward or gift thoult haue
And thou ſhalt hau't.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: If I performe it, I require your houſe
Do euer open reſt at my command,
Be you within or not: that though vnbidden
I ſtill haue roome and welcome giuen me

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.p: Here is my hand thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Then I will ſettle
To the attempt.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Whom heare I here? ô Thraſo!

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Thou perhaps hear'ſt not the Newes?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Why do I ſee you then
Here in theſe quarters?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir as reſting onely
Vpon your loue.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Know'ſt thou not, what to reſt on?
I tell thee ſouldier, if I here hence forward
Do take thee in this ſtreete; th'art a dead man:
It will auaile you little then to ſay
You ſought ſome man, or were to paſſe this way.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Nay good ſir this not fitteth.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I know you are not of ſuch boiſtrous temper.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Pray yet firſt giue me hearing
Of a few words; which when I ſhall haue ſaid
As you do like it, grant it.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Thraſo remoue your ſelfe a little of.
Firſt I moſt earneſtly requeſt you both
Thus farre to credit me; that what herein
I do, is chiefely for my owne ſake meant:
But if the ſame may likewiſe further you,
Twere ſimpleneſſe in you not to admit it.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: I thinke fit, you take vnto you
This riuall ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: How ſaiſt? take him to vs?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Pray but conſider this; you Phaedria
Do ſurely loue your Thais companie,
And to fare well: little you haue to giue her,
And ſhe of force muſt be ſupplied largely.
Now then to ſerue her turne, and ſpare your coſt,
There's none can be more fitting, or more vſefull
Then is this ſouldier: firſt has where withall,
And then there's none more lauiſh the's a foole
A prating babling foole, a dolt, a blocke,
will ſnore you out whole dayes, and nights together.
And for the feare that ſhe may happe to loue him,
That's needeleſſe: you may pelt him out at pleaſure:

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: What were we beſt to do?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Then adde this too;
(Which I accompt a thing of greateſt moment.)
None fares more richly, none more daintily.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Its mar'le but we haue neede at any hand
Of this ſame fellow.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: You take the right courſe. One thing more I beg,
I may be made one of your companie:
I haue beene long now rowling of this ſtone.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: And haeria in requitall, twixt you both
I tender him to ſlout, and feede vpon.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Thraſo, now
You may draw neere at pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Gnato, ſay
How ſtands my caſe?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: How? theſe men knew you not
After I told, hem your conditions,
Praiſ'd you according to your deeds and vertues;
I wonne my ſute.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: It was well done, I thanke thee
I neuer yet could come in any place
But all men doated on me.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.l: Said I not:
How gracefull was his tongue for eloquence?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: Thou left'ſt out nothing. Paſſe we this way hence.

div.head: Addition. Epilogue by Gnato.
div.l: AThens and Rome full many ages hence
Haue through Menanders, Plautus, Lerence Art
(In ſeuerall names but ſounding to one ſence)
Seene this our Eunuch, grac'd the ſlatterers part.
Thoſe Greeke and Latine playes had their deſart,
Earning loude plaudits from their audience.
Our Engliſh Author (h'has no Poets name,
Nor (ſayes he) may he dare ſuch ſtile to take)
Puts me vpon the brunt to ſtand the blame:
Himſelfe not venturing his approach to make,
Nor to your cenſure his raw skill to ſtake.
He thinkes me now wrought, paſt all feare and ſhame.
But I the name and nature here caſt off:
I ſee amongſt you no proud ſouldier,
No ſelfe blowne bladder, I may pricke or ſcoffe.
Our Nation is not guiltie of the former,
Nor could I well play the flatterer:
No maile if I the name now ſeeke to doſſe
Yet though I doſſe the fawne; ſtill bend I low,
Crauing your gentle pardon for vs all,
And thanke you for your patience hitherto
So kindely ſhowne to vs in generall.
Oh, would you deigne ſome further grace withall
Vpon our ſwouning writer to beſtow;
He dyes in feare leaſt you miſlike his paine,
Your well clap'd hands call him to life againe.

div.p: PAge 1. l 3. I thinke, r. Sir thinke. p. 2. l. 20. one ſome, 1. ſome one. p. 8 l. 23. round abouts, r. windeabouts. p. 9. l. 25. nothing, r. noting. p, 36. l. 1. now I, r. I. l. 16. leaue the courſe, r. I leaue. p. 39 l. 6. this the, r. tis the p. 17. l. 22. ought, r. oft. p. 49. O Charinus, r. who's that Oh Charinus.

Argument l. 56 hath downe, r. hath ſet downe. Char. of Au. l. 7 ſtragling, r. ſtrugling. Pro. l. 64. playes, r. play. Ac. 1. S. 1. l. 10. not one, r. one. betweene 14 and 15 line, put in this verſe, You are caſt in Law, you may goe ſhake the care. l. 29 ſhee it. r. ſhee yet. l 32. ſhall allay, r. ſheel allay, S. 2. l. 87 louely woman, r. lonely woman. l. 88. kinſmen, 1. kinſman. l. 112. and Eu. an Eu. l. 113. great Ladies haue, r. great Ladies onely haue. Act. 2. Sc. 3. l. vlt. his ſouldiers, r. the ſouldiers Sc. 5. l. 70. I wormeling, r. I a wormeling l. 99 whom, r. home. Ac 4 Sc. 2 l 3 ought, r. oft. l. 10. torne, r. turne. l. 12. be pent, r. here be pent. Sc. 3. l. 35. and accident, r. an accident l. 68. i • be, r. if 't be. l. 7. Simatio & Sannto, r. Simatio and Sannto l. 14. but, r. that. l. 15. or Souldiers, r. our Souldiers l. 27. thinkes, r. Thinkſt l. 39. aſſure, r. aſſur'd. Act. 5. ſc. 1. l. 19. leſt 'him. reade, left 'hem. pag. 104. l. 6. he cauſe. reade, caſe, l. 18. Ile-but, r. I'l—, But.
